description: Perhaps from Latin quippe (“indeed”), ultimately quid (“what”).

entries.meaning: A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort or comeback; a gibe.
examples: Quips, and cranks, and wanton wiles.

verbs.description: quip (third-person singular simple present quips, present participle quipping, simple past and past participle quipped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To taunt; to treat with quips.
examples: He did not really mind being quipped; the city gentlemen made him used to that sort of thing.
